metadata.titleEn: Global Cryospheric Extent and Phenology Dataset (1979-2016)
metadata.description: Under the background of global warming, the cryosphere is one of the most sensitive spheres to climate change. The cryosphere is the world's largest reservoir of freshwater resources. The change of the cryosphere has an important impact on the energy exchange, water resources, ecology and disaster process of the earth atmosphere system. Therefore, it is particularly important to explore the response of cryosphere change to climate change. Using satellite remote sensing data, reanalysis data, and observation data, the cryosphere elements were integrated to build a global scale cryosphere range and phenology dataset for 1979-2016. The results can be used to further study the response mechanism of the cryosphere to climate change, as well as to provide basic support for the research of ecosystems, carbon cycle, etc.
metadata.instructions:
1. Data format: mat
2. Projection: WGS84
3. Data size: 380MB
4. Variable name: cryosphere range, phenology (first day, last day, freezing period)
5. Data unit: None

background: According to ongoing temperature analyses, the average global temperature on Earth has increased by slightly more than 1°C since 1880. Furthermore, the near-surface atmosphere in high-latitude and high-altitude regions has warmed faster than elsewhere. Observational records of ocean heat content show accelerated warming as well. The global temperature rise has resulted in a worldwide cryospheric reduction as evidenced by, for example, a strong increase in ice loss, pervasive ice sheet mass loss, large decreases in sea ice cover and thickness, and terrestrial snow cover extent decreases. The cryosphere plays a major role in earth's climate system. Most cryospheric assessments focus on one or more of its components and their response to climate change.
research objective: We therefore determine such a holistic estimate and quantify changes to the hemispheric and global cryosphere due to climate change, by synthesizing sea ice, snow cover, and frozen ground extents into one global cryospheric extent data set. Our findings highlight the importance of assessing the cryosphere as a whole, and provide a way to quantitatively estimate its overall changes.
methods: To combine the three major cryospheric components into one global cryospheric extent data set, we grid all products into one uniform 0.25° × 0.25° spatial resolution using nearest neighbor interpolation at the daily time scale. For the ground surface freeze/thaw status, the twice daily (AM and PM) values were averaged into daily resolution, and also interpolated to the 0.25° × 0.25° spatial resolution using nearest neighbor interpolation. For snow cover, ERA-Interim snow depths are used to identify snow cover based on daily snow depths greater than 1 cm. The snow cover extent data set also again includes ice sheets, that is, Greenland and Antarctica. Sea ice extent is available at the daily time scale, except for the time period from November 1, 1978 to August 19, 1987 when data were only available every other day. For this period, we interpolated the sea ice extent into daily resolution. Finally, we combined all three data sets into one, where each grid cell was classified as cryosphere if it contains at least one of the frozen surface types: frozen ground (including ice sheets), snow cover, or sea ice cover. If a grid cell contains one or more cryospheric variables, it is defined as one single cell occupied by cryosphere. Based on this classification, we produced the daily cryospheric extent data set. To assess the long-term spatiotemporal variability of the cryosphere, we calculate both the area extent and the percent cover. For area extent, we calculated the daily areas for the NH, SH, and the whole globe. We also create monthly and annual area extents to quantify changes in cryospheric area extent based on the daily area extent datasets in each year. All area extent calculations are based on equal area projections. The percent cover is calculated as the ratio of days that each grid contains cryospheric cover during the defined time scale, for example, per month, or per year. To characterize the timing and duration of cryospheric cover, we identify the first date (FD), last date (LD), duration (DR), and number of days (ND) of cryospheric cover. We investigate anomalies of monthly and annual variables with respect to the 1981–2000 long-term average. Trends are calculated using linear regression of the anomalies. Statistical significance of trends was established using two-tailed t-tests at the 95% confidence level. Time series are smoothed using wavelet analysis. The uncertainty of the trends is also determined using the 95% confidence level. The daily cryospheric extent is verified using the GSOD product. To verify our reconstructed daily cryosphere extent data set, 14,310 stations were used for validation. The observed daily cryospheric status at each station is determined based on the above method using observed daily minimum air temperature and snow depth. Next, the reconstructed daily cryospheric extent value at each station location is extracted. The observed (GSOD) cryospheric status is then used to verify our reconstructed daily cryospheric extent.
dataset: Data sets used in this study include sea ice, snow cover, and near-surface frozen soils. Area extent of both the Greenland and Antarctic Ice Sheets is included in either snow cover or near-surface frozen soil products. We essentially synthesize three major data products: near-surface frozen soil data, snow cover extent data, and sea ice area extent. To analyze the cryospheric extent's relationship with climate change, air temperature data are used. We also use in-situ station observations to validate our global cryospheric area extent. Sea ice is a major cryospheric component for the Arctic and Antarctic oceans. Here, we use the daily sea ice extent data set for 1978–2016 with 25 × 25 km spatial resolution from the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC). For global snow cover extent, we use snow depth from the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts interim reanalysis (ERA-Interim) for 1979 to 2016 with a spatial resolution of 0.25° × 0.25°. Daily ground surface freeze/thaw status data span from 1979 to 2016 and are available at 25 × 25 km resolution from NSIDC. Global monthly average air temperature data were obtained beginning in 1979 from the University of East Anglia's Climatic Research Unit time series version 4.04. Station data are used in this study to verify our daily cryospheric extent data set. The global summary of the day (GSOD) product is produced by the National Centers for Environmental Information with inputs from integrated surface data. The GSOD data set is made up of more than 28,000 stations from 1929 to the present, and includes minimum, maximum, and mean air temperature, snow depth, air pressure, dewpoint temperature, wind speed, and precipitation variables.
findings: During 1979–2016, global cryospheric area extent lost approximately 87 ± 11 × 10^3 km2/yr, with a decrease of 102 ± 9.7 × 10^3 km2/yr in the NH that was partly offset by an increase of 14.6 ± 4.4 × 10^3 km2/yr in the SH. The first day of cryospheric cover was delayed by 3.6 days at a rate of 0.95 days/decade, and the last day advanced by 5.7 days, at a rate of 1.5 days/decade. The duration and number of cryospheric cover days decreased by 8.7 days and 7.6 days over the study period, respectively. These variations of global cryospheric extent are correlated with rising air temperatures.

Definition.Question: What does 'cryospheric extent data set' mean in the context of climate change studies?
Definition.Answer: In the context of climate change studies, a 'cryospheric extent data set' refers to a comprehensive collection of data that quantifies the spatial extent of the cryosphere, including components such as sea ice, snow cover, and frozen ground. This dataset integrates these elements to provide a holistic view of the cryosphere's coverage on a global scale, helping to analyze changes and their implications for climate systems.

Definition.Question: What does 'percent cover' represent in the analysis of cryospheric data?
Definition.Answer: 'Percent cover' in the analysis of cryospheric data represents the proportion of time a grid cell is covered by cryospheric elements (such as snow, ice, or frozen ground) over a specified time period, like a month or year. It provides an understanding of the temporal dynamics of the cryosphere by indicating how frequently a region is covered by these elements within the given timeframe.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the trends in global cryospheric area extent differ between the Northern Hemisphere and Southern Hemisphere, and how might data collection methods contribute to these differences?
Comparison.Answer: The trends in global cryospheric area extent show a decrease of 102 ± 9.7 × 10^3 km2/yr in the Northern Hemisphere, whereas the Southern Hemisphere exhibits an increase of 14.6 ± 4.4 × 10^3 km2/yr. These differences might be attributed to variations in data collection methods such as the types of cryospheric components measured (e.g., sea ice versus frozen ground) and regional climate variations that influence the observations captured by satellite and reanalysis data.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of multiple cryospheric components into a single dataset improve the understanding of global cryospheric changes?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating multiple cryospheric components such as sea ice, snow cover, and frozen ground extents into a single dataset allows for a holistic estimate of the cryosphere's response to climate change. This approach provides a comprehensive view of the overall changes and highlights the importance of assessing the cryosphere as a whole. By synthesizing these components, researchers can quantify changes to the hemispheric and global cryosphere, offering insights into its relationship with climate trends.

Interpretation.Question: How do the observed changes in the timing and duration of cryospheric cover correlate with rising air temperatures, and what does this imply about future cryospheric trends?
Interpretation.Answer: The observed changes, such as the delay in the first day and advancement of the last day of cryospheric cover, correlate with rising air temperatures. This correlation suggests a reduction in the duration and number of cryospheric cover days over time. These trends imply that future cryospheric trends will likely continue to show a decrease in cryospheric area extent and duration, driven by ongoing global temperature increases, impacting water resources, ecological systems, and energy exchanges within the earth's climate system.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the integration of satellite remote sensing data, reanalysis data, and observational data when constructing a global-scale cryospheric extent dataset?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The integration of satellite remote sensing data, reanalysis data, and observational data is crucial for capturing the various elements of the cryosphere, such as sea ice, snow cover, and frozen ground extents, to create a comprehensive global-scale cryospheric extent dataset. Each type of data provides unique insights that, when combined, allow for a holistic assessment of the cryosphere in response to climate change.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons for validating global cryospheric extent datasets with in-situ station observations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Validating global cryospheric extent datasets with in-situ station observations is essential to ensure accuracy and reliability. Station data provide ground-truth validation, verifying the reconstructed daily cryospheric extent by comparing it against observed cryospheric status, which helps in identifying any discrepancies and improving dataset robustness.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the likely consequences on data accuracy and spatial resolution when interpolating sea ice extent data to daily resolution using nearest neighbor interpolation?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Interpolating sea ice extent data to daily resolution using nearest neighbor interpolation can impact data accuracy and spatial resolution by potentially introducing errors or artifacts, especially during periods with sparse data. This method of interpolation might not capture finer spatial details, leading to less precise representation of sea ice extent changes over time.

Causal Consequence.Question: What effects might arise from combining different cryospheric components such as frozen ground, snow cover, and sea ice into one comprehensive dataset on research findings?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Combining different cryospheric components into one comprehensive dataset can provide a holistic view of the cryosphere's overall response to climate change. However, it may also lead to challenges in maintaining the integrity of individual component data, potentially affecting precision in analyzing specific cryospheric processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of integrating various cryospheric elements such as sea ice, snow cover, and frozen ground into a unified global dataset?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of integrating these cryospheric elements is to create a holistic estimate that quantifies changes to the hemispheric and global cryosphere due to climate change. This integration highlights the importance of assessing the cryosphere as a whole, providing a comprehensive way to estimate its overall changes and supporting further research on the cryosphere's response to climate change.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended outcomes of analyzing the long-term spatiotemporal variability of cryospheric components in relation to climate change?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended outcomes include understanding the cryosphere's area extent and percent cover changes over time, identifying trends and anomalies, and correlating these changes with rising air temperatures. This analysis is crucial for assessing the cryosphere's response to climate change and providing foundational support for studies on ecosystems and carbon cycles.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to integrate satellite remote sensing data, reanalysis data, and observational data into a comprehensive cryospheric dataset?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To integrate these data sources into a comprehensive cryospheric dataset, the process involves synthesizing sea ice, snow cover, and frozen ground extents into one global cryospheric extent data set. This is achieved by gridding all products into a uniform 0.25° × 0.25° spatial resolution using nearest neighbor interpolation at the daily time scale. For the ground surface freeze/thaw status, twice daily (AM and PM) values are averaged into daily resolution, while snow cover and sea ice extents are adjusted to daily scales as well.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the long-term spatiotemporal variability of the cryosphere be assessed using the available data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The long-term spatiotemporal variability of the cryosphere can be assessed by calculating both the area extent and the percent cover. Daily areas for the Northern Hemisphere, Southern Hemisphere, and the whole globe are computed, with monthly and annual area extents derived to quantify changes. The percent cover is determined as the ratio of days each grid contains cryospheric cover during a defined time scale, such as per month or year. Anomalies of monthly and annual variables are investigated with respect to the 1981–2000 long-term average, and trends are calculated using linear regression of the anomalies.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What validation methods are employed to ensure the accuracy of a reconstructed global cryospheric extent dataset?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Validation of a reconstructed global cryospheric extent dataset involves using in-situ station observations. For example, the daily cryospheric status at each station is determined using observed daily minimum air temperature and snow depth. This observed status is then compared with the reconstructed daily cryospheric extent value at each station location. For verification, the GSOD product, with inputs from over 28,000 stations, is used to ensure the accuracy of the cryospheric extent data set.

Enablement.Question: What methods and technologies are used to integrate different cryospheric components into a unified global extent data set?
Enablement.Answer: To integrate different cryospheric components into a unified data set, major cryospheric components such as sea ice, snow cover, and frozen ground extents are synthesized into a global data set. Products are gridded into a uniform 0.25° × 0.25° spatial resolution using nearest neighbor interpolation at the daily time scale. Snow cover is identified using ERA-Interim snow depths, and sea ice extent data is interpolated to daily resolution. The unified data set is created by classifying each grid cell as part of the cryosphere if it contains any frozen surface types.

Enablement.Question: How do the specific conditions of high-latitude and high-altitude regions enable more rapid warming and subsequent cryospheric reduction?
Enablement.Answer: The near-surface atmosphere in high-latitude and high-altitude regions has warmed faster than elsewhere, which contributes to more rapid cryospheric reduction. This warming has resulted in increased ice loss, ice sheet mass loss, and decreases in sea ice cover and thickness as well as terrestrial snow cover extent.

Enablement.Question: What data validation methods are utilized to ensure the accuracy of reconstructed daily cryospheric extent in global datasets?
Enablement.Answer: Data validation is performed using the GSOD product, which involves 14,310 stations for validation. The observed daily cryospheric status at each station is determined using observed daily minimum air temperature and snow depth. The reconstructed daily cryospheric extent value at each station location is extracted and compared against the observed cryospheric status.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using satellite remote sensing data, reanalysis data, and observational data in constructing a global cryospheric dataset?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of satellite remote sensing data, reanalysis data, and observational data is highly effective in constructing a global cryospheric dataset, as it allows for comprehensive integration of various cryospheric components such as sea ice, snow cover, and frozen ground. This approach provides a holistic view and enables the analysis of long-term trends and variability, which is crucial for understanding the cryosphere's response to climate change.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how can integrating in-situ station observations enhance the validation process of global cryospheric datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating in-situ station observations can significantly enhance the validation process of global cryospheric datasets by providing ground-truth data that helps verify the accuracy of satellite-derived or reanalysis products. It strengthens the dataset's reliability by offering localized observations, which can help identify discrepancies and improve the overall model calibration, thus contributing to a more robust understanding of cryospheric dynamics.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out how near-surface frozen soils are integrated into a comprehensive cryospheric extent dataset.
Assertion.Answer: Near-surface frozen soils are synthesized into the global cryospheric extent dataset along with snow cover and sea ice by using data products that include both near-surface frozen soil data and snow cover extent. The spatial resolution is unified to 0.25° × 0.25° using nearest neighbor interpolation.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how the timing and duration of cryospheric cover are determined in this kind of research.
Assertion.Answer: The timing and duration of cryospheric cover are characterized by identifying the first date (FD), last date (LD), duration (DR), and number of days (ND) of cryospheric cover. The data is analyzed for anomalies against a long-term average (1981-2000) and trends are calculated using linear regression.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how datasets are verified for accuracy when compiling a global cryospheric extent dataset.
Assertion.Answer: The accuracy of the global cryospheric extent dataset is verified using observational data from station observations, such as the Global Summary of the Day (GSOD) product. Observed daily cryospheric status based on minimum air temperature and snow depth is compared with the reconstructed daily cryospheric extent for validation.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the methods used to integrate satellite remote sensing data, reanalysis data, and observational data for constructing a comprehensive cryosphere dataset.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methods involve gridding all cryospheric components into a uniform 0.25° × 0.25° spatial resolution using nearest neighbor interpolation at the daily time scale. For the ground surface freeze/thaw status, twice daily values are averaged into daily resolution. For snow cover, ERA-Interim snow depths greater than 1 cm are used, and sea ice extent is interpolated to daily resolution when necessary. All components are then combined into a single dataset by classifying each grid cell as cryosphere if it contains any frozen surface types.
